timeline.bodyText: Any particular reason why so many finalists would be a good idea?
timeline.author: triceo

replies.bodyText:
No, but with a normal amount of memory we can handle this.
Figuring out the MAX_SIZE on which these so many finalist would be 100% of the time a bad idea, is impossible.
It would be a good guesstimate at best, so if we get it wrong: an potential risk for silent, surprising misbehaviour in how the algorithm reacts in certain conditions. That's a risk I am unwilling to take (low chance it happens but too high impact if it does).
This MAX_SIZE isn't meant to distinguish between good and bad. It's to distinguish between bad without OOME trouble and bad with OOME.
replies.author: ge0ffrey

timeline.bodyText: Wouldn't it make sense to instead remove the least recent finalist? Or perhaps the worst finalist?
timeline.author: triceo

replies.bodyText:
All moves in the finalistList have the same score (which is the reason that in most cases, it's typically size 1 to at most 100). There is no way to distinguish out the worst one.
I doubted about ignoring the oldest or the newest.
Removing the oldest in an ArrayList (not ArrayDeque) has a big0(n) perf cost. Ignoring the newest doesn't.
Both the first move evaluated and the last move evaluated in the same step with the same score, have equal right to be selected - recency doesn't count (there is no changes in the steps).
So I went for ignoring the newest.
replies.author: ge0ffrey
